Acceptance Test-Driven Development with Shiny

Posted on January 21, 2025 by jakub::sobolewski in R bloggers | 0 Comments

[This article was first published on jakub::sobolewski, and kindly contributed to R-bloggers]. (You can report issue about the content on this page here)
Want to share your content on R-bloggers? click here if you have a blog, or here if you don't.

I‚Äôve created this Shiny project to showcase how I practice Acceptance Test-Driven Development with {shinytest2}. The app is very simple ‚Äì calculate net income from income and expenses inputs. Even in such a simple example we can see:

  • how to start a Shiny project by writing a test first. I‚Äôm using {rhino}, but the same method can be used for any Shiny framework you use,
  • how to interact with the app from tests in a way that won‚Äôt break them often by using {selenider} instead of {shinytest2} snapshots,
  • how to evolve your project from the simplest solutioan, to implementing more usable app ‚Äì here we‚Äôre starting with a ‚Äúforgetful‚Äù app, then implementing persistent storage,
  • how to cycle between ATDD and TDD ‚Äì from specifying user‚Äôs needs to working on implementation details that are hidden from users,
  • how using robust selectors allows us to refactor UI without breaking tests.

üí° The best way to explore the repo is to go commit by commit listed in the README.

See how we can go from a failing test to a working app. I know, it‚Äôs a very simple app, but the same process can be applied to any project, no matter how complex it is.

Check it out here: https://github.com/jakubsob/shiny-acceptance-tdd
